stem: A 6-week-old infant is brought to the clinic for 'projectile vomiting' after every feeding. The nurse palpates the infant's abdomen. Which finding, combined with the history, is most indicative of hypertrophic pyloric stenosis?

options.text: A sausage-shaped mass in the right upper quadrant.
An olive-shaped mass in the epigastric area.
Visible peristaltic waves from right to left.

rationale.correct: Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is characterized by an enlargement (hypertrophy) of the pyloric sphincter, leading to gastric outlet obstruction. The classic physical finding is a firm, non-tender, 'olive-shaped' mass in the epigastric region (to the right of the umbilicus). This mass is the hypertrophied pylorus itself.
rationale.incorrect: Sausage-shaped mass and currant jelly stools are classic for intussusception. Visible peristaltic waves do occur in pyloric stenosis, but they typically move from left to right (as the stomach tries to force the contents through the obstruction), not right to left.

answerBreakdown.label: A
answerBreakdown.content: Choosing "A sausage-shaped mass in the right upper quadrant." represents a misinterpretation of the gathered cues or a failure to prioritize physiological needs.

answerBreakdown.label: B
answerBreakdown.content: Identifying "An olive-shaped mass in the epigastric area." is a priority nursing action/finding essential for maintaining patient safety in this scenario.

answerBreakdown.label: C
answerBreakdown.content: "Currant jelly-like stools." is a common distractor; it is either a non-specific finding or an action that follows more urgent stabilization.

answerBreakdown.label: D
answerBreakdown.content: Choosing "Visible peristaltic waves from right to left." represents a misinterpretation of the gathered cues or a failure to prioritize physiological needs.

clinicalPearls: The mass is often best palpated when the infant's stomach is empty and the abdominal muscles are relaxed.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: When multiple options describe symptoms of GI obstructions, differentiate by the 'Shape' of the mass (Olive = Pyloric | Sausage = Intussusception).

mnemonic.title: P-O-V
mnemonic.expansion: Projectile vomiting, Olive-shaped mass, Visible peristalsis (Left to Right).

reviewUnits.heading: Pediatric Gastroenterology
reviewUnits.body: Infants with pyloric stenosis are at high risk for metabolic alkalosis due to loss of gastric acid. Pre-operative care focuses on fluid and electrolyte correction.
